Dear Student,

You have been shortlisted by JPMC for the online test scheduled for tomorrow - Sept 6 from 11 AM (morning). Test link will be sent from the company end before the test.

[Important] The email addresses - pu.bitspilani@gmail.com and pu.bitspilani2020@gmail.com are both genuine addresses used for communication by the Placement Unit. For the case of raising any query from your end, please mail to pu.bitspilani2020@gmail.com

Please ensure you have followed the below steps (also sent in an earlier mail) already or please do so by the deadline today. Ensure that your personal mail (with which you have applied on the JPMC portal) has been submitted in the google form given in Step no. 2.


1.       Open the portal (link given at the end, first please read the instructions)

2.       Click Apply Now and sign in with your JPMC career site username and associated email address (use Personal mail only, Don't use BITS mail, Also put your personal mail in this form). Compulsory to fill this form before you apply on the portal.

-       If you do not have an account with JPMC, make one or you don't recall your password click forgot your password and follow the instructions


-       You will be required to attach your resume with a Photograph (use Superset Resume only), kindly update your prior internship experience with other skills [optional]

-       In case the campus does not appear in the application form, please select ‘other’ and mention the campus in the free text field

4.       Click “Submit” to officially submit your application – a confirmation will be sent to the email address on your account when your application has been received.

To submit your application for JPMC QR ( company portal link) click here  
Please note -
Only for the cases where your CGPA/Class X/Class XII marks are not verified yet, please fill the following google form - Link. The requests will be verified by September 4 - 5 PM. Please don't fill in case of re-verification and resume verification. You may use the resume if it shows proper CG and Class X and XII marks. Please don't bother for such requests.

Regards,
Placement Unit

Dear Student,

Hope you are busy with your Test 1 preparations.
Please note the tentative test and ppt schedule for Day 1 of the Internship Season 2020-21 to keep you informed in advance.
Day 1 Test Schedule
20th Sept, Sun
21st Sept, Mon
Day 1 Interviews on Sept 22-24 
HUL Interviews on Sept 21

    CGPA Cutoff for Day 1 companies will be 7.0 (might be higher for some companies)

Goldman Sachs and JPMC will be hosted on Day 1 with a total of 6-8 companies.
Remaining companies will be disclosed as they will be opened for applications between Sept 16-19.


    Applications for all Day 1 companies will be opened via Superset or Google Forms during Sept 16-19 for a window of 16-18 hours. Please make a note to apply during that window only and not to bother with requests afterwards.
    Reiterating, the first offer you get is your last offer in the Internship Season 2020-21.

    Ensuring technical support (electricity backup, network) is students' responsibility and the PU doesn't take any accountability for the lack of same at your end. No requests for issues at your end will be entertained.

    Please refrain from any malpractices during the online assessments as it takes a lot of efforts to bring companies, especially in these times and any single act of misconduct could render those efforts of the PU futile.

    All the best for the Internship Season and stay active on your mails and the slack channel for regular updates.


Regards,
Placement Unit

Dear Student,

The online test for Adobe is today (on 22nd Sept) at 9 PM. The test link will be active from 9 PM to 10 PM

 


 


 

Dear Students,


Greetings from Adobe India! Thank you for your application for an internship. We are as excited to begin the process as you are.

We have scheduled the test on – 22nd Sept. Please login anytime between 9 PM to 10 PM to start the test.

 

Please find the HackerRank instructions below.

 

    This is a timed test. Please make sure you are not interrupted during the test, as the timer cannot be paused once started.
    Please ensure you have a stable internet connection.
    We recommend you to try sample test for a couple of minutes, before taking the main test if you are not familiar with this test environment. 
    All questions are compulsory.
    The test window is from 9 PM to 10 PM, please make sure you log in during this period
    There is no negative marking for attempting any question incorrectly.
    All questions of Section 1 to 4 are single correct Multiple-Choice Questions.
    For questions in Section 5, the marking will depend on the number of test cases passed.

 

We trust you to abstain from any irregular conduct during the selection process. The HackerRank tool has stringent plagiarism checks in place to detect any element of malpractice during the test. If we do make any such findings, it will affect your candidature. Adobe reserves the right to disqualify such candidates from the internship process.

 

We really value your capabilities and intent to intern with Adobe. Look forward to providing you with positive hiring experience. Thank you and all the best.


Any cases of malpractices and malafide attempts will be dealt with seriously and with strict actions such as debarment from the internships and the Placements Season. The Placement Unit has the best interests of all sincere and honest students at its heart and will take any measures to ensure the same,


Regards,
Placement Unit

Dear Candidate,

Thanks for your interest in an opportunity with Flipkart! Now, as the next step of the recruitment process, you are hereby advised to undergo our Computer Based Online Recruitment Test (AMCAT).


    A Personal Computer / Laptop only.
    A working webcam connected with the system.
    Smooth and uninterrupted Internet connectivity (throughout the testing session)
    Your Photo ID Proof (you will be asked to take the picture along with your Photo ID proof while taking the test) 


We would like to reiterate that you must take the test on a computer with a webcam and dedicated/ smooth Internet connectivity. If your test gets stuck at any point, you can resume the test using the same login details, this will enable you to restart the test at the same place where you got stuck. For more details on this, please read the instructions given below.


    Google Chrome (version 60 and above, the latest version is preferred)
    Mozilla Firefox (version 60.0 and above, the latest version is preferred)
    In case you're taking the test on Windows 8, make sure you use the latest version and disable all the popups/ notifications.
    Block all other system/application pop-ups prior to starting the test.


Procedure for taking online Test


    For taking the AMCAT exam, copy and paste the URL provided in the email and follow the instructions.
    Enter the username and password provided to you in this mail.
    You will be automatically prompted to Allow your Camera to be enabled, please ACCEPT the request. Do not switch off or remove the webcam or alter it’s position post initial snapshot)
    Fill the registration form and click on Continue (please use the registered email ID).
    A 15-digit number will appear. This is your AMCAT ID. Note it and keep it safe with you.
    Ensure that while you open this link no other tab/window/link is opened simultaneously on your system else your scores will not be processed.
    Overall test duration is 90 mins.
    Do not attempt to take screenshots as the same will lead to disqualification.
    There are plagiarism check mechanisms built in the platform, so do not copy paste code from the web or from your peers as it may lead to a lower score / disqualification.
    Also, internet connectivity should be smooth.
    Please complete the assessment in one go.



Actual Online Test details


User Name - f20170828@pilani.bits-pilani.ac.in
Password - 9PEbnVR

Please complete the assessment in full in one sitting.

For any issues related to the Online Test, please reach out to us on techsupport@aspiringminds.com or Click Here to chat with us.


    There is no negative marking.
    If somehow your test is stopped in between, (due to power failure/internet disconnection) wait for five minutes. Now, you may login again using the login details shared in the mail. Please resume the Test only after 5 mins of halting the Test.

Please note that you can attempt the test only once using this User ID and Password.

 

Thanks,
Aspiring Minds

    Any Intel-based system preferably with P4 processor and above.

        Candidates should sit in a well-lighted place in order to ensure a hassle-free test experience.
        Candidates can view their image during the test at the left bottom side of the screen (in case it is not visible, scroll down on the test window). This will help the candidate to be visible to the camera's extent.
        In case multiple faces or no faces are detected during the test, the test will stop but the timer will continue.
    Candidates should not try to navigate away from the test window, as this may lead to the auto-completion of their test.
    Post the completion of the first assessment, the candidate will be redirected to a page stating that "Your attempt has been submitted successfully. Thank you for taking the test." Here the candidate needs to click on the "Proceed" button in order to move to the next (second) assessment.

Important

tps-notification

Dear Students, 

We have partnered with Upraised to launch ‘Associate Product Manager (APM) Internship Programme’ in our college. The entire programme is free of cost for the students.

This is a unique programme that selects students, trains them for necessary PM skills and provides an opportunity to do internship in a product role (either as Associate Program Manager or, Product Analyst) with high growth companies such as PayTM, Unacademy, Zomato, Oyo, Yellow Messenger, MPL, Zeta and many others. Internship is guaranteed once you are selected. It's zero-risk for students since it's absolutely free. This is why we’ve partnered with Upraised.

Please note that Students already having internship offers are not eligible for this.

 

        You have to clear 3 rounds to be accepted to the APM Internship Programme.
        On registration you will receive instructions on how to appear for Round 1 selection test. Based on your performance you will be able to progress to future rounds.

 

Check more details in FAQ below.

 



 


 

Best Regards,

Placement Unit

 


    Am I eligible for Upraised’s programme if I already got an internship from college?
    No.

    Will I be eligible for campus opportunities if I get an offer from Upraised?
    No after getting final internship offer i.e. #4 above. However, you can appear  in campus opportunities till you get a final offer.

    How will the students be selected?
    There will be 3 rounds in the process. For the first round, all registered students will be required to take the KYS Test conducted through the app. If you meet the cut-off, you will be selected to move on to subsequent rounds.

    Tests do not require any prior preparation. To better acclimate with the test environment, we have a 5 days trial test. More information will be shared with registered students through email.

    Is there any CGPA criteria for application or selection?
    Yes, 6.9 and above CGPA and performance in the selection process.

 

    Will I get a stipend? 

All the 25 opportunities are paid internship opportunities and will carry competitive stipend. But final details will be shared before interviewing with firms (step #4)

 

    Why are the selected candidates being trained? 

To ensure that they perform well during internship and can get PPO. Learning covers necessary PM skills for the internship. Delivery will be self-serve & schedule will be flexible. During this period, you’ll be required to put in ~1 hour per day. 

 

    What are partner colleges?
    APM Internship Programme is launched across top 25 engineering colleges across India.

    What do Associate Product Managers do?
    Product management is one of the hottest jobs in the market. These are cross-functional high ownership roles in tech firms that comprises a good mix of ideation, user research, implementation, stake-holder management, data analysis and experimentation. It is a business (non-coding) role.

Best Regards,
Placement Unit

We will be leveraging the HackerRank platform to conduct the online coding test.
    Before starting the test, you have been asked to mention important details such as your name, roll number, email ID, college name etc. Please mention these details accurately. These details should match the details mentioned in your registration on the JP Morgan Chase Careers page, as these details will help us to correctly identify each and every candidate.
    The test duration is 75 minutes.
    This is a coding test of 100 marks having 2 programming questions, each of 50 marks. It is mandatory to attempt both the questions. There is no negative marking.
    Please use any programming language of your choice. The most popular programming languages used are Java, C, C++ and Python.
    Please ensure strong internet connectivity at your end. Candidates who get logged out of the test for any reason will not be able to log back in again.
    It is mandatory to keep your laptop/desktop webcam switched on during the entire duration of the test. You will be able to start the test only after you have switched on your webcam.
    The HackerRank platform will automatically capture random images of all candidates at random intervals during the course of the test, and report plagiarism attempts. We have zero tolerance to copying/cheating/plagiarism and any attempt to do so will result in immediate disqualification from the selection process.
    Please give the test continuously in one go. The test will run in a new tab and switching between tabs while giving the test is considered a violation. Similarly, it is not allowed to move away from your desk during the test. Please ensure to be ready with all required test material such as stationery, water etc. before starting the test.

Regards,

Abhishek Jain

Internship Coordinator

    The HackerRank platform will automatically capture random images of all candidates at random intervals during the course of the test, and report plagiarism attempts. We have zero tolerance to copying/cheating/plagiarism and any attempt to do so will result in immediate disqualification from the selection process.
    Please give the test continuously in one go. The test will run in a new tab and switching between tabs while giving the test is considered a violation. Similarly, it is not allowed to move away from your desk during the test. Please ensure to be ready with all required test material such as stationery, water etc. before starting the test.

Hi Everyone,
There's been a lot of questions regarding the process for the Google SWE profile. I have attached the most common questions below. Please go through them once for clarifications.

1. Is it an on-campus or off-campus opportunity?
Ans. It is an on-campus opportunity.

2. If I get placed in Google will I be allowed to sit for other companies?
Ans. No, if you get this you will be deregistered from the placement process. 

3. Can people sitting for PS in sem 1 apply?
Ans. Yes, it is an open company anyone graduating in 2022 can apply.

4. ICPC is there on the same day, can the test be rescheduled?
Ans. No.

5. Will edge cases regarding CG (5.98 etc.) be entertained?
Ans. No.

6. Can we use a non-superset resume?
Ans. Preferably not.

7. I want to update my CGPA on superset will that be done?
Ans. Yes. Please change it on superset, it will be approved by 7 PM tomorrow.

8. I made a mistake while filling the form. Can I edit my responses?
Ans. Yes, the form can be edited before the deadline.

Also, please make sure that the CGPA you have filled in the form and the CGPA in your resume are the same. 

If there are any other questions please let me know. 

--

Hi Varkeychan Jacob,

Thank you for your interest in the Google SWE Internship / Graduate opportunity (India). To help better understand your coding capabilities, we would like to invite you to participate in Google’s Online Challenge. We hope you’re excited!

When will it go live?


How does it work?

There are two coding questions to be attempted within a 60-minute time limit. The timed challenge will automatically record your submission at the 60-minute mark.


Google Online Challenge Name
	


Google Online Challenge ID
	

491240154384

Challenge Passkey
	

763985

To participate, please register here!













    Please enter your “Google Online Challenge ID” as your username e.g. 123456789012

    and “Challenge Passkey” as your password e.g. 123456; as indicated in the screenshot below.

    Please DO NOT use any other login methods e.g. sign up for a new account or continue with a pre-existing login. You will only be able to login and participate in the Online Challenge using the Challenge ID and Passkey assigned to you.




How do I prepare and practice for the challenge?


    Make sure you are familiarised with Computer Science fundamentals and revise data structure and algorithm fundamentals.

    Write code that is easy to read and understand and ensure that it gives you the correct output. Handle corner cases correctly.

    Understand programming languages well to make good use of existing data structures or standard libraries.

Please use this practice link with a sample coding question to familiarize yourself with the coding editor, as well as the list of available programming languages. Please login using your assigned Online Challenge ID and Passkey above. You will NOT be evaluated on the practice round. 

What are the next steps after the challenge?

Challenge results will not be posted online. Our team will be in touch only if you are selected to proceed to the next step. Please remember that we evaluate your candidacy comprehensively and the challenge is only one part of our program evaluation process.

If you have any questions please refer to our FAQs. If you cannot find the answer to your question, you can email googleonlinechallenge-ticket@google.com.

We look forward to your participation and wish you the best of luck!

Cheers,

Google’s Online Challenge team

Dear student,

Hope you are doing well and staying safe.

We have observed that a very low number of students are practicing the Aptitude tests (Program-A). Given that placements for semester-1 is right around the corner, and a majority of companies across all domains have aptitude tests as initial screening, we as the Placement Unit strongly advise you to not underestimate the value of these tests. Major filtering of students from the company's end happens in the Aptitude test, making it essential for a student to take it seriously. Historically, we have observed that students who start early and practice regularly have always qualified the initial screening tests easily. The quality of these tests are at par with the actual company tests, also sometimes certain questions are found common between the two. 

We strongly advise you to start preparing by practicing these tests, as onccemente the Placement Season begins, students are found lacking time for preparation. There are company specific coding + aptitude tests included in the subscription, apart from the whole Aptitude preparation module making it beneficial to all the students.

We wish you all the best for the Placement Season ahead.

Please contact us if you face any issues regarding the tests or the platform.

Regards,
Placement Unit.

Hello Varkeychan Jacob Varkeychan Jacob,

Thank you for your interest in Amazon’s Software Development Engineer (SDE) opportunities! We would like to invite you to complete our assessment, which is the first step of our interview process. Please read the instructions and follow the link below.  If you have any questions, please route them through your Training and Placement department as they are the primary point of contact.
 
Online Assessment Overview
The assessment consists of four components, a code debugging section (20 minutes), a coding test (70 minutes), a workstyles assessment (20 minuntes) and a reasoning ability section (35 minutes). At the end of the test, there is a feedback survey that is required to be completed. Browser usage is logged, so please do not access any sites that require login or are private repositories. For the coding sections, manage your time wisely! If you get stuck on a code debug problem, move to the next problem and revisit the questions as needed.  During the reasoning section, you will not be able to skip and return to questions.

The time remaining will be clearly displayed on the screen. You will not be able to stop the timer once you have started each test.  

 
Instructions

    Do not click the assessment link in this email until you are ready to take the assessment in full.
    Though you will not need to download any additional software or applications to complete the assessment, please refrain from utilizing “print screen" as you will be locked out and your session will be terminated. Please also refrain from using copy/paste within the assessment environment.
    We recommend you complete the coding portion solely using the assessment environment provided and ensure it is compiled and submitted successfully.
    Ensure you have a reliable internet connection. We recommend using the latest versions of Google Chrome or Mozilla Firefox with both pop-ups enabled and ad blockers disabled.

 




Next Steps
After completion of the assessment, a processing page will appear verifying your completion.  It may take a few minutes to process. If it does not redirect you after a few minutes, it is okay to close your browser. You will receive an email confirmation once everything has been submitted with next steps. It is mandatory to submit the feedback survey. Your test is incomplete without the submission of the survey.


 
Troubleshooting


    Double check that pop-up blocker and ad-blocker has been disabled on your browser.  Try Mozilla, if you are using Chrome
    If problems persist, try clearing cookies or loading in Incognito/Private Browsing mode


    This may take a few minutes to process.  If it does not redirect you after a few minutes please close your browser and you will receive an email confirmation of completion.
    If you do not receive a confirmation email, please inform your college Training and Placement office.

For technical issues that occur during the assessment, please examine closely where you left off.  It is ok to close your browser and reaccess the assessment link.  Your timer will be paused once you disconnect from the session.  Please reaccess the link, accept terms, and scroll down to click the blue "Resume Test" button.  Do not repeatedly refresh the screen. 

For additional troubleshooting steps, go here for FAQs to troubleshoot or use the live chat feature for assistance.

If technical issues cannot be resolved, please notify your college Training and Placement office. The Amazon Student Programs team will work with you Placement office and guide for next steps.

We are pleased to inform you that JSW has tied hands with World Steel Association on their steelChallenge-16 competition. This yearly competition is recognised by the global steel community as the preeminent competition to engage students and industry professionals to showcase their ability to make the best quality steel at lowest cost.  This is a brilliant opportunity to find and nurture talent for the steel industry and needless to say is a great opportunity for the participants to learn and grow.

The World Steel Association opened registration for the 16th edition of steelChallenge. steelChallenge is the biggest steel industry competition where students and industry employees can test their skills using the sophisticated online process simulations delivered by steeluniversity. 

New this year, there will be carbon footprint requirements for the steel grade to reinforce the steel industry commitment to reduce the footprint from its operations.

 

steelChallenge-16 will take place over two rounds. The Regional Championship will take place online on 24 November 2021 from 5.30 PM. Participants will use a combination of the Electric Arc Furnace and the Secondary Steelmaking simulators, producing the required steel at the lowest cost.  They will be asked to produce steel and refine it to the proper chemistry and temperature.


    Americas,
    Asia – East and Oceania,
    Asia – North,
    Asia – West, and
    Europe and Africa.

 

The World Championship will be in April 2022.

All participants successfully completing a simulation run will get an official completion certificate by steeluniversity. In addition, when registering for the competition, participants will get a full pack of learning resources including e-learning courses, 3D interactive models and practice simulations.

The Regional Champions will receive a cash prize, a regional championship certificate and the invitation to the World Championship. They will also gain recognition as the global industry’s promising new generation of metallurgists and will be featured on the steeluniversity website. 

The World Champions will get the steelChallenge trophy and receive an additional cash prize and a certificate.

__

 

JSW will also give out certificates, merchandise and goodies for each student who registered and appeared for the challenge! Hurry Up! 

 

Participation is absolutely free. Participants can register for steelChallenge-16 now at steeluniversity.org. Steps to register are attached below. Through our partnership we have been able to give out free promo codes to interested participants which will exempt them from paying for the challenge. Please also find attached below the promo codes to register and participate. The promo codes are to be filled in during the registration process.

Trump's Syria withdrawal plan shocks allies
US president says Islamic State has been defeated, but defence officials want to maintain a US military presence in the region
facebook twitter google+
The Week

Dear Varkeychan,

Donald Trump’s abrupt decision to withdraw US troops from Syria will be welcomed by Russia and Iran, both of whom have been working hard to supplant American influence in the region.

The biggest losers from the move meanwhile are likely to be US allies, such as the Kurds and Israel – not to mention the US itself, which could end up being drawn back into the region if, as some expect, the withdrawal helps Islamic State forces regroup.

from Arion McNicoll,
Editor, TheWeek.co.uk
@TheWeekUK
	

from Arion McNicoll,
Editor, TheWeek.co.uk
@TheWeekUK
main headline

shock decision
Is the US withdrawal from Syria premature?
To the surprise of his allies and the frustration of senior officials Donald Trump has decided to pull out all US troops from Syria, claiming Islamic State had been “defeated” and their job is done.

There are currently around 2,000 US troops on the ground in the war-torn country where they are primarily training local forces to combat Islamic State (IS). They have helped rid much of north-eastern Syria of the terrorist group, but pockets of fighters remain.

Nevertheless, “a complete, rapid withdrawal, if confirmed, would upend assumptions about a longer-term US military presence in Syria” reports Al Jazeera. READ MORE ▸

US economy
Fed raises rates despite pressure from Trump
The US Federal Reserve has raised interest rates again, following a two-day meeting to discuss the state of the US economy.

The move, which adds 0.25% to official interest rates aiming to reach a target between 2.25% and 2.5%, came despite unprecedented public lobbying by Donald Trump, who had pre-emptively called a rate rise “foolish” and “crazy”.
READ MORE ▸

more haste, less speed
Labour MP urged to resign after guilty verdict
A Labour MP has been suspended from the party and urged to resign from parliament after being found guilty of repeatedly lying to avoid a speeding ticket.

Fiona Onasanya was found guilty of perverting the course of justice following a retrial. She had been accused of colluding with her brother to avoid having three points deducted from her licence for speeding – and then doubling down in a series of lies that became increasingly hard to defend.
READ MORE ▸
main headline

briefing
Are plastic toys dangerous?
UK consumers warned to avoid plastic toys after a large number were found to contain chemicals banned by the EU. READ MORE ▸

productivity study
Self-promoters ‘do less but get ahead at work’
People who are good at self-promotion generally do less work than their colleagues but still get ahead faster, a new productivity study of 28 British workplaces has found.

Research from the Ashridge at Hult International Business School examined the engagement levels of teams of workers, across seven different employment sectors, such as health, government, transport and not-for-profits.
READ MORE ▸

soft start
World’s second-largest IPO a ‘flop’ for SoftBank
Shares of SoftBank Corp, involved in Japan’s largest-ever initial public offering (IPO), have plummeted after the stock made a dismal debut on the Tokyo stock exchange.

SoftBank Corp is the mobile telecommunications arm of Japan’s SoftBank Group, run by billionaire chief executive Masayoshi Son.
READ MORE ▸

tall tales
Police recover stolen house
And other stories from the stranger side of life.

READ MORE ▸

DOWN TO BUSINESS
Thursday morning markets
Asian markets slumped this morning, following Wall Street’s lead after the US Fed increased interest rates by 0.25%. Japan’s Nikkei was also hit by a disastrous IPO for SoftBank Corp, the second-largest IPO in history.

Gold prices steadied after the US Fed hinted at fewer rate hikes in 2019, while oil prices resumed dropping, erasing gains from yesterday’s session amid oversupply fears.


on this day
20 December 1803
The French flag is lowered for the last time in New Orleans to mark the formal transfer of the Louisiana Purchase from France to the USA for $27 million.

Strategies for Debriefing Healthcare Scenarios


Presented by Center for Advanced Pediatric and Perinatal Education (CAPE), a part of Stanford Medicine

Healthcare professionals work in complex, high-risk environments where safety is paramount. Yet, they often don’t have the necessary time and tools to analyze their performance during training in order to develop strategies to overcome weaknesses and reinforce strengths. Debriefing is one of the most effective methods for empowering healthcare professionals of all experience levels to improve their individual and team performance. By fostering a nonjudgmental and productive environment you can help your team hone their ability to provide consistent, high-quality, safe patient care.

In this webinar, CAPE’s directors, Lou Halamek, M.D. and Nicole Yamada, M.D., will use an interactive discussion and video exemplars from CAPE’s new online debriefing program to highlight and analyze four foundational strategies from CAPE’s 20 Strategies for Effective Debriefing.


    How to clearly communicate expectations for how a debriefing will be conducted

    How to begin debriefings in an objective and efficient manner

    Ways to avoid creating defensiveness during debriefings

The Week

Dear Varkeychan,

“I would do a deal with the devil to get a proper Brexit,” Nigel Farage said recently on his LBC radio show. But the MEP may not have to call on Lucifer to get his wish.

With the Conservatives reportedly plotting an electoral tie-up, this afternoon’s top story looks at how a Tory-Brexit Party pact might work.

from Arion McNicoll,
Editor, TheWeek.co.uk
@TheWeekUK
	

from Arion McNicoll,
Editor, TheWeek.co.uk
@TheWeekUK
main headline

'secret talks'
What a Tory-Farage pact would mean
Nigel Farage is in “secret talks” with Tory party donors about a pact for a snap general election, it has been reported.

The Daily Telegraph claims the Conservatives might offer not to stand candidates against Farage’s Brexit Party in dozens of seats, in a bid to ensure the UK leaves the European Union by the end of October.

“Under the idea, the Brexit Party could agree not to stand against Tory Brexiteer candidates, while the Tories would not fight Metropolitan Labour seats in the north of England where the Brexit Party is strong,” reports the Telegraph.
READ MORE ▸

britain's next PM
Who won the First Tory leadership TV debate?
Five of the six MPs hoping to become the next Tory leader and prime minister clashed last night in the first televised leadership debate of the contest. So who won last night’s debate?

READ MORE ▸

schoolgirl killer
How a child murderer ended up working at an Oxford primary school
A woman jailed for killing a schoolgirl as a teenager was able to teach at primary school in Oxford for almost a year without disclosing her conviction, it has emerged.

Iria Suarez-Gonzalez, now 35, became “one of Spain’s most notorious killers” after she and a friend stabbed 16-year-old Clara Garcia to death in 2000, the Oxford Mail reports. According to media reports from the time, the pair - who cut Garcia’s throat and stabbed her 32 times - were driven by a desire to know “what it would feel like to kill someone”.

DOWN TO BUSINESS
Monday afternoon markets
London’s leading share index inched higher today in line with marginal gains across Europe, “as rises in banks outweighed the impact of a profit alert from Germany's Lufthansa on airlines, while UK contractor Kier Group skidded to a life low”, reports Reuters.

Shares in easyJet and British Airways owner IAG took a hit after the German airline giant issued a shock profit warning, admitting that its short-haul business had been dented by fierce competition and amid concerns over surging fuel costs.

Shares in the US benefited from slight gains as markets opened this morning, while the big mover was Sotheby’s, whose shares were up 58%, after French businessman, Patrick Drahi, agreed to buy the auction house for $3.7bn.

What does prorogation mean for your money?
	  	
  	There are many questions being asked by investors today as a result of yesterday's decision to prorogue parliament.

    Will this trigger a vote of no confidence?
    Will the pound fall again?
    Will people "sell" and do their research later?

MoneyWeek's executive editor, John Stepek says “I'd expect turbulence over the next couple of months, certainly. But if you're an active investor and stock picker, I'd use that time to build up your cash reserves and make a watchlist of stocks that you want to buy. This is the kind of torrid atmosphere that creates buying opportunities for quality companies at usually low valuations."

Important Information

    For passengers travelling on a domestic sector of SpiceJet to an international sector on SpiceJet or vice versa, the free baggage allowance and cabin baggage allowance of International sector will be applicable. Passengers travelling on a domestic Sector of SpiceJet and scheduled for a connection on another airline to/ from an international destination, are allowed Free Baggage Allowance as per the class of booking. 


    Failure to do so can result in your booking being cancelled and the fare retained. Web check-in facility is available on www.spicejet.com, for all flights originating from India only, but is not available for Group Bookings, Defense Bookings, Student Bookings, Infant Bookings and flights originating from Srinagar, Jammu.
    As Andaman and Nicobar Islands being the Restricted Area under Foreign Nationals (Restricted) Order 1963, hence the provision of Restricted Area Permit (RAP) has been relaxed for the visit by Foreigners to 30 islands in A & N Islands. However, the citizens of China, Afghanistan & Pakistan and those who have origin in these countries and citizens of Myanmar intending to visit Mayabunder & Diglipur in North & Middle Andaman District continue to require prior approval of Ministry of Home Affairs to gain entry and avoid any inconvenience.
    Boarding gate closes 20 minutes ( 45 minutes in case of Kabul and 25 minutes in case of other international travel ) prior to scheduled departure time and failure to board within the stipulated time can result in denied boarding with fare retained.
    Passengers doing web check-in shall be responsible for ensuring their hand-baggage meets the physical dimension limits the weight limits, and must pay for excess cabin baggage (if any) at the airport check-in counter. There will be random checks at boarding gates for hand baggage size and weight, and if found oversized or overweight, INR 400/ Kg (effective from 22nd June, 2018) will be chargeable, and additionally the bag may be taken from the passenger to be placed in the hold. 


    For all foreign (Non-Indian) credit / debit card payments, the card must be produced for physical verification at the airport check-in counter if the passenger is the cardholder. Incase the cardholder is not traveling, it is mandatory for the passenger to furnish to the airport check-in staff a physical copy of the front side of credit / debit card duly authorized by the cardholder, along with cardholder’s valid proof of identification. In the absence of such credit / debit card or copy and/or identity mismatch, we will be constrained to refuse the boarding. You may however pay through acceptable alternate mode of payment at the time of check-in and continue your journey. 


    Changes/cancellation in the bookings can be made only up to 2 hour prior to scheduled departure time ( 4 hours in case of international travel ) upon payment of a change/cancellation fee (amount depends on the type of far e purchased, as advised at the time of booking) along with difference in fare, if applicable. All promo/sale fares are restrictive fares and are refundable (only statutory taxes). Certain promo/sale fares do not permit changes to the flight. Please check restrictions on the fare while booking 



Additional Terms and Conditions

    Self or Voluntary offloading after boarding the flight by the passenger is strictly not permitted, except in an unforeseen event of medical emergency or similar cases, such as death of relatives for which the passenger will have to provide evidence, to the satisfaction of SpiceJet. SSelf or Voluntary offloading causes unwarranted inconvenience to other travelling passengers, delay in operation of flight and also the airline incurring additional costs for such delays. In case the passenger offloads himself/herself for any cause other than as mentioned above, SpiceJet will cancel the entire ticket for each such passenger for the subject travel and also any further transportation (whether under single or multiple PNR) with no refunds. Each such passenger who is off-loaded shall be liable to a off-loading fee of Rs.10,000 per passenger which will be levied and to be paid immediately upon off-loading. Additionally, SpiceJet reserves the right to recover from each such passenger any and all costs (whether direct or consequential) incurred due to disrupted operations including but not limiting to removal of baggage, flight delays, disruptions and misconnections and inconvenience to other passengers.
    Excess baggage charges will be payable for carrying baggage over the permissible limit. It can be pre-booked (at discounted rates) up to 6 hours prior to scheduled departure time of the flight on spicejet.com, by calling our Reservations hotline and at our airport ticketing counters.
    For free baggage allowance & Excess Baggage Charges on international sector (s), kindly refer to T&C's on www.spicejet.com
    We strongly recommend that all valuables (e.g. camera, jewellery, cash, electronics, perishables items, etc.) and medication shall be carried in cabin baggage only. SpiceJet assumes no responsibility for any pilferage/ damage to valuables incase they are carried in check-in baggage and the passenger shall be doing so at their sole risk and consequences.
    Passengers travelling to UAE/Oman from India for employment/tourist purposes shall be requiring an “OK TO BOARD” comment in the PNR. Kindly get in touch with your visa issuing agency for the same.
    All Foreign Nationals/ Non-Resident Indians are mandatorily required to carry their Passport with valid visa for their travel.
    Name changes are not permitted on your booking. Please ensure that passenger’s booking name matches with proof of identification.
    Any booking made using special fares/ promo codes/ discount coupons etc. shall be subject to terms and conditions of respective promotion in addition to the general Terms of Carriage.
    Flight schedules are subject to change and applicable regulatory approvals.
    Certain fares could carry a restriction related to change/cancellation and policy. In case you do not wish to opt for restricted fare, you can book two separate PNRs for each sector without the benefits/restrictions of the return fare.
    Passengers are advised to compulsorily retain the boarding pass until exiting the terminal for security reasons. Passengers on via and connecting flights should keep their boarding pass handy for physical check at transit points.
    SpiceJet allows free checked baggage of 15kgs per passenger for all domestic flights on all fares EXCEPT Hand Baggage Only fares promo/sale. For Hand Baggage Only fares promo/sale, there is no free checked baggage allowance.
    Passengers on these fares who wish to check baggage will be charged Fare Type Change Fee of Rs.400 at the airport for up to 15kg. Baggage in excess of 15kg. is subject to a fee (INR 400 per kg. with effect from 22nd June, 2018) to be paid at the airport at check-in.
    Hand Baggage Only fare promo/sale is Non-refundable. Changes are permitted at applicable charges
    Carriage of Samsung Galaxy Note 7 is prohibited in checked-in and hand baggage.
    For safety reasons, dangerous articles, such as those listed below, must not be carried in passenger's baggage.
    b.     Corrosives such as acids, alkalis, mercury and wet cell batteries and apparatus containing mercury.
    c.     Explosives, munitions, fireworks and flares, ammunition including blank cartridges handguns, fireworks, pistol caps.
    d.     Flammable liquids and solids such as lighter refills, lighter fuel, matches, paints, thinners, fire-lighters, lighters that need inverting before ignition, matches (these may be carried on the person), radioactive material, Briefcases and attaché case with installed alarm devices. Oxidizing materials such as bleaching powder and peroxides.
    e.     Poisons and infectious substances such as insecticides, weed-killers and live virus materials. Other dangerous articles such as magnetized materials, offensive or irritating materials.
    f.      Carriage of dry cell batteries, knives, scissors, sharp instruments, tools, firearms, ammunitions, and toy replicas are prohibited in the Passenger cabin.
    g.     Personal motorized vehicles (powered by lithium battery) similar to hover-boards, self balancing device, scooter etc. will not be permitted on Spicejet flights.
    h.     Spare Lithium ion batteries, power banks and e-cigarettes may be carried as cabin baggage only. Lithium ion batteries of watt-hour (Wh), rating above 100 Wh but not exceeding 160 Wh, will be permitted. These batteries must be individually protected to prevent short circuits.
    a.     cancels the flight; or
    b.     prepones the flight by sixty (60) minutes or more; or

    ii.     to be accommodated on alternate flight(s) for the same sector for next or preceding seven (07) days from the original date of journey, subject to availability and SpiceJet’s discretion in the event SpiceJet.

March 23, 2020
Author Headshot	

By Margaret Lyons

Television Critic

Dear Watchers,

Thank you to all who wrote in to share their social-distancing viewing rituals and projects. It sounds as if a lot of folks are finally summiting Mt. “Sopranos,” and I wish all of them a blessed voyage.

I hope those of you who can stay home are staying home, and I hope those of you who are working in essential services are getting the support you need.

Stay safe, be cool, and I’ll see you Wednesday.
Continue reading the main story
ADVERTISEMENT
	
I Want Something Engrossing



This five-part documentary is among the best nonfiction series ever made. It blew me away when it premiered in 2016, and I have thought about it hundreds of times since, both its literal accomplishments in format and its broader ideas and themes. It’s about O.J. Simpson, but it’s also about everything — race and sports, of course, but also California history, models of justice and the light-bending heft of fame and power.
Continue reading the main story
ADVERTISEMENT
	

I Want Something Emotional
Laura Dern, left, and Luke Wilson in “Enlightened.”Nicola Goode/HBO

‘Enlightened’


Social distancing can make one a little numbed, so reconnect to the human endeavor with this beautiful two-season HBO dramedy about the tricky parts and some of the good parts of being alive. Laura Dern stars as Amy Jellicoe, who thinks maybe she can change the world, starting with her corrupt company, or maybe herself, or her mom, or her ex-husband. The show’s prickliness can take some getting used to, so I encourage you to give the show four episodes to get its vibe. It has some of the emotional ideas of a fairy tale — the sense of longing, the bold individualism, the urgency — but the grounding and brininess of a social satire. If you’ve been reading more poems lately and feel you need to take your heart for a walk, watch this.
Continue reading the main story
ADVERTISEMENT
	
I Am Going Stir Crazy
Now we can all study the blade.Annette Brown/History



Sometimes all that’s left is watching people stab buckets of sand with homemade swords. God bless. This obstacle-course series is like a hot tub for your brain — I wouldn’t do it 24/7, but there are times you just need to be blissed out and boiled stupid. Competitors bring their own blades of choice and put them to the test with a series of strange challenges, like slicing through a raw chicken hanging from a string, or cutting through a watermelon dropped from the ceiling. There’s no blood and guts, and the show emphasizes safety and sportsmanship, so it’s also fine for most ages. I have seen every episode.
Mia Goth, left, and Anya Taylor-Joy in a scene from “Emma.”Focus Features


With theater chains shuttering multiplexes to prevent the spread of coronavirus, major studios have scrambled to make new theatrical releases available for home viewing. Since our last Monday newsletter, several major studio films were released online early, and this week’s newly available titles include a few more early arrivals — along with the year’s biggest flop and the story of a violin prodigy who vanished during World War II.

Unless noted, the films can be purchased on the usual platforms — Amazon, Apple TV, Google Play, Vudu and YouTube. A rental option is usually available within a few weeks, though some are available for short-term rental now. (Click here for more details.)


‘Emma’ (available now)
Everything has been emphatically embellished, so much so that it initially seems that [the director Autumn de Wilde] has adapted the material using Wes Anderson software. — Manohla Dargis (Read the full review here.)

‘The Hunt’ (now)
An almost-successful attempt to do for class and ideology what Jordan Peele’s “Get Out” did for racism. — A.O. Scott (Read the full review here.)

‘The Invisible Man’ (now — A Critic’s Pick)
This shrewd, cleverly updated version plays with the different meanings of “romance” by fusing the basic conceit from [H.G. Wells’s] uncanny tale with the fallout of an abusive romantic relationship. — Manohla Dargis (Read the full review here.)

‘Onward’ (now; on Disney Plus April 3)
The mild, one-joke amusement of ‘Onward,’ directed by Dan Scanlon (“Monsters University”), comes from the clash of the mundane and the fantastical. — Ben Kenigsberg (Read the full review here.)

‘Birds of Prey’ (coming Tuesday)
Unlike “Joker,” this exercise in R-rated fan-flattery allows itself, and the audience, to have some fun with its noisy, hectic, self-conscious riffing on the conventions of comic-book-based entertainment. — A.O. Scott (Read the full review here.)

‘Bloodshot’ (Tuesday)
“Bloodshot” runs out of meta tricks before it is over, and David S.F. Wilson, who borrows his visual vocabulary from Tony Scott and Michael Bay, delivers action sequences with such choppy continuity that viewers may be as confused as [its hero]. — Ben Kenigsberg (Read the full review here.)

‘Dolittle’ (Tuesday)
[The director Stephen Gaghan] apparently ran into issues while making “Dolittle,” leading the studio to bring in other filmmakers. Even so, the story remains thin, the performances wobbly, the laughs infrequent. — Manohla Dargis (Read the full review here.)

‘The Gentleman’ (Tuesday)
The point is cleverness and looking cool … mostly the movie is about [Guy Ritchie’s] own conspicuous pleasure directing famous actors having a lark, trading insults, making mischief. — Manohla Dargis (Read the full review here.)

‘Just Mercy’ (Tuesday)
Just Mercy is saved from being an earnest, inert courtroom drama when it spends time on death row, where it is opened up and given depth by two strong, subtle performances, from Jamie Foxx and Rob Morgan. — A.O. Scott (Read the full review here.)

‘The Song of Names’ (Tuesday)
The movie never quite justifies the contrivance of its puzzle-box construction. Parlaying this material into an arty whodunit cheapens the real history invoked. — Ben Kenigsberg (Read the full review here.)
Also This Week
Essie Davis in “Miss Fisher and the Crypt of Tears.”Acorn TV

    The movie sequel to the Australian series “Miss Fisher’s Murder Mysteries,” “Miss Fisher and the Crypt of Tears,” is now streaming on Acorn. It has a sort of diet “Indiana Jones” vibe and can be a little on the hokey side, but the show’s charm and glam are back in full force, too. Become a hat person! Embrace your truth!

Wait, one more thing …

If you are considering adding a streaming service to your current lineup, note that a lot of them are offering promotional extended free trials right now. Slate has a roundup of most of them, and Amazon, Hulu and Netflix also have free 30-day trials (as usual). If you’re looking for classic, foreign and art-house films, Criterion Channel is offering a 14-day trial and Mubi is now charging $1 for three months’ access.

Statistical errors are surprisingly common in medical literature. Fortunately, you don’t need a degree in statistics to catch these errors. In many cases nothing more than common sense and simple arithmetic is required. In addition, there is an ever-increasing number of free, easy-to-use online statistical tools that facilitate error detection. Today we’re launching the Unsplash Book Club 📚

	

Unsplash Logo
	
Unsplash Book Club 

‪One of the biggest challenges of launching a new book is promotion.‬

‪It’s doubly hard in today’s environment with no book tours or conferences.

We wanted to do something about this while sharing interesting, new books with you.

So today, we’re launching Unsplash Book Club ‪— a featured collection of books coming soon.‬

Each book we partner with, will be giving free-use access to never-before-seen visuals from their book. Sometimes it will be a first look at the cover. Sometimes it will be excerpts or visuals from the book.
See the Unsplash Book Club
	
	
How Innovation Works with Matt Ridley

Our first featured book is How Innovation Works by the incomparable Matt Ridley. Matt is is the award-winning, bestselling author of several books, including The Rational Optimist and The Evolution of Everything. His books have sold more than one million copies in thirty languages worldwide.


What excites us about Matt’s book is learning more about what underlying conditions lead to innovation. Matt’s book is full of examples from steam engines to search engines and even life itself. We’re excited to learn about these examples and think about what we may be able to apply to Unsplash and in life.


How Innovation Works hits North American shelves today and the UK, June 25.‬ You can buy or pre-order a copy on Amazon.


If you’d like to join the Unsplash Book Club, enter your email here. We’ll be launching new books every so often and you’ll get an update as soon as we do.

🙌
Mikael and the Unsplash team

‘Air bridges’ raise hopes of holidays abroad
Quarantine rules may be relaxed between some countries
facebook twitter google+
The Week

Dear Varkeychan,

If the warm weather has whetted your appetite for a summer holiday, this afternoon’s newsletter contains mixed news. 

On the one hand, travellers bound for a select few destinations may benefit from an intriguing - if vague - “air bridge” arrangement... but everyone else will be stuck in quarantine.

from Holden Frith,
Digital Director
The Week
@TheWeekUK
	

from Holden Frith,
Digital Director
The Week
@TheWeekUK
main headline

Reaction
‘Air bridges’ give Brits hope of holidays abroad
Would-be holidaymakers’ hopes of trips abroad this year have been boosted by proposals to exempt Britons who travel to countries with low coronavirus infection rates from strict new quarantine rules. 

The plan to form so-called “air bridges” between the UK and lower-risk countries was floated by senior Tory MP Huw Merriman and has won the backing of Transport Secretary Grant Shapps. 

The proposal comes a week after Health Secretary Matt Hancock warned that it was “unlikely that big, lavish international holidays are going to be possible for this summer”, as a result of a “blanket” 14-day quarantine for arrivals to the UK that is due to be introduced from next month. 
READ MORE ▸

open borders
Why did UK take so long to introduce quarantine?
The UK is set to join the growing number of countries that have introduced quarantine rules for people arriving from abroad - but critics are asking why Boris Johnson’s government waited so long. 

Brussels-based news site EUobserver reported in March that nine European Union states had closed their borders entirely, and Germany - which has been lauded for its coronavirus response - has had quarantine measures in place since early April.
READ MORE ▸

heavy toll
Which countries put on most weight in lockdown?
Health Secretary Matt Hancock has announced that the government is bringing forward plans to tackle obesity, as people across the UK struggle to control their weight during the coronavirus lockdown.

And the UK isn’t alone in its weight wars during the global pandemic. According to The Telegraph, Italians emerged from two months of lockdown an average 2kg (4.4lbs) heavier.
READ MORE ▸
main headline

briefing
Could a ‘federal Britain’ have beaten coronavirus?
A less centralised system might have empowered local governments - or led to chaos READ MORE ▸

global charge
McDonald’s accused of worldwide ‘systematic sexual harassment’ of employees
An international coalition of trade unions has filed a complaint against McDonald’s that accuses the fast-food chain of failing to tackle “rampant” sexual harassment of its employees.

The complaint lists numerous incidents of harassment and abuse at McDonald’s restaurants across the globe, including attempted rape and indecent exposure in the US, a promotion in exchange for sexual acts in Brazil, and a hidden camera in a women’s changing room in France, reports The Guardian.
READ MORE ▸

Ronan Farrow
Is Harvey Weinstein’s nemesis ‘too good to be true’?
US journalist Ronan Farrow has racked up a string of awards and a huge following with his exposes about powerful men who abuse their position to harass and assault women.

But The New York Times media columnist Ben Smith has taken a deeper look at some of The New Yorker reporter’s work and, as The Guardian puts it, “found him wanting”.
READ MORE ▸

comment round-up

“There is a reason why Jacob Rees-Mogg’s passionate defence of in-person parliamentary democracy went viral last week. ‘Simply a series of prepared statements made one after another. That’s not the House of Commons doing its proper duty its proper role of scrutiny of the Government.’ The proper democratic system of this country has been fundamentally diluted.”

Last normal photograph

A Twitter thread asking users to share their “last normal photo” from before the coronavirus outbreak has gone viral, with celebrities among the thousands of people getting in on the action.

Access Stanford Webinars On Demand

We’ve posted some new webinars on Stanford Online. Sign up to watch them anytime, for free. Join us, and learn something new in under an hour!

Effective Data Visualization in the Era of COVID-19

In a crisis, data is especially critical to understanding challenges and formulating solutions. In this webinar, Stanford Associate Professor Kristin Sainani introduces basic concepts in data visualization, including how to graph different types of data, principles of effective data visualization, and how graphs can mislead. Watch now >>

How to Be a Good Boss During Trying Times

Managing people through ambiguity and anxiety isn’t easy. Join Bob Sutton and Huggy Rao in this webinar to learn management techniques that will help you communicate, support, and lead your teams during these trying times. Watch now >>

How to Innovate Faster and Better During COVID-19

Don’t let this time of uncertainty discourage innovation and creativity. In this webinar, Jeremy Utley and Perry Klebahn from the Stanford Design School (d.school) will offer techniques to help you create more ideas, tackle problems, and energize your remote teams. Watch now >>

Data-Driven Storytelling

The power of data lies in the stories it tells. In this webinar, Cheryl Phillips will walk you through the process of transforming raw data into effective narratives and visuals. She’ll cover best practices in searching for data, cleaning and processing it, and ultimately making sense of it. Watch now >>

Cyber Security and COVID-19

As thousands of people transition to remote work, more businesses become vulnerable to attacks, but you can prevent breaches by understanding the cyber landscape and learning to maintain cyber security through this pandemic and beyond. In this webinar, Neil Daswani explores the lessons learned from recent mega-breaches and examines key takeaways in today's new reality. Watch now >>

WHO says pandemic is ‘getting worse’
The spread of Covid-19 is accelerating around the world
facebook twitter google+
The Week

Dear Varkeychan,

The coronavirus news is decidedly mixed this morning, with caution optimism in the UK set against a gloomier picture worldwide.

Testing data show declining infection rates in most parts of the UK, even as lockdown restrictions are lifted, but the global pandemic is yet to reach its peak.

from Holden Frith,
Digital Director,
TheWeek.co.uk
@TheWeekUK
	

from Holden Frith,
Digital Director,
TheWeek.co.uk
@TheWeekUK
main headline

daily briefing
Ten things you need to know today
1. WHO says coronavirus pandemic is ‘getting worse’
The spread of Covid-19 is accelerating globally, with infections doubling in the past six weeks, the head of the World Health Organization has warned. Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said the pandemic has yet to reach its peak. “In most of the world, the virus is not under control,” he said. “It is getting worse … more than 544,000 lives have been lost. The pandemic is still accelerating.”

2. Court rules that prosecutors can see Trump tax returns
The US Supreme Court has ruled that Donald Trump’s financial records can be examined by prosecutors. However, the court said they did not have to be shared with Congress. The ruling has “cemented the fact that the public isn't going to get a look at his tax returns before the November election”, says CNN. His predecessors have made their financial records public voluntarily. 

3. ‘Work out to help out’ as gyms set to re-open
Gyms, pools, nail bars and tattooists will be allowed to re-open from 25 July as the government lifts restrictions on leisure facilities and beauty services in England. Team sports - starting with cricket – will also be permitted to resume. Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden urged people to “work out to help out”. Two reports charting coronavirus cases in England show the number of people with the disease is falling.

4. Government ‘will borrow half a trillion’ as Covid costs mount
The government is on course to borrow half a trillion pounds over two years as the cost of its response to the coronavirus pandemic mounts. The Institute for Fiscal Studies estimates that this year’s deficit will reach £350bn - a record for any peacetime year. The Daily Telegraph says the “debt mountain” will “pose a challenge to Rishi Sunak and his successors as chancellor for many decades to come”.

5. US announces China sanctions over Muslim camps
Washington has announced sanctions against China for its human rights violations against Muslim minorities in Xinjiang. Beijing is accused of mass detentions, religious persecution and forced sterilisation of Uighurs and others. Rights groups say up to a million Muslims have been detained in high-security prison camps across Xinjiang province. However, the authorities deny any mistreatment of Muslims.

6. Boots and John Lewis cut 5,300 jobs as retail wobbles
Dozens of stores will close and more than 5,300 people will lose their jobs as the coronavirus pandemic takes another chunk out of retail. Boots is cutting 4,000 jobs – or 7% of its workforce – by closing 48 opticians outlets and reducing staff at its head office in Nottingham. John Lewis says it plans to permanently shut eight of its 50 stores, including branches in Birmingham and Watford.

7. BBC suggests staff include gender pronouns in their emails
The BBC is encouraging staff to include their preferred pronouns in email signatures, to make transgender and non-binary colleagues feel more welcome. New guidance, posted on the corporation’s intranet, says adding pronouns at the foot of emails - for example, he, she or they - is a “small, proactive step that we can all take to help create a more inclusive workplace”.

8. Boris Johnson to roll out anti-obesity initiative
The prime minister is poised to launch an anti-obesity drive, starting with a ban on supermarket promotions of unhealthy food. Stores will be prevented from offering buy one, get one free deals on targeted products. However, campaigners are disappointed that Boris Johnoson is likely to delay the introduction of a 9pm watershed on the advertising of unhealthy food.

9. Top charities say lockdown is harming dementia patients
Charities say that families of care home residents with dementia should be treated as key workers. They have written to the government to argue that visits and care from family members are “essential” to residents’ mental and physical health and that lockdown restrictions have had “damaging consequences”. The letter is signed by the leaders of charities including Dementia UK and the Alzheimer’s Society. 

10. China warns of virus deadlier than Covid-19 in Kazakhstan
Chinese officials have warned that an “unknown pneumonia” with an alarming mortality rate has broken out in Kazakhstan. “The death rate of this disease is much higher than the novel coronavirus,” the Chinese embassy wrote in a warning to Chinese citizens in Kazakhstan. The local health ministry says it has recorded more than 32,000 cases of pneumonia between June 29 and July 5 alone, along with 451 deaths.

Today’s front pages
‘You'd better shape up’
Reporting on the reopening of gyms, swimming pools and leisure centres, Metro tells readers “You’d better shape up.” The Times says that it is time for the nation to “work out to help out”.

The Mirror prefers to focus on the “Jobs hell at high street icons” after cuts at Boots, Burger King and John Lewis. The Financial Times leads on the same story, reporting that Rishi Sunak is “under fire” for his “poorly targeted” support.

“They’ve sunk our cruises,” complains the Daily Mail, splashing the news that the Foreign Office has warned against travel on cruise ships. It says the “dramatic intervention” is a “huge blow” to the travel industry.

Spain insists it is safe after UK launches new quarantine
Country’s largest coronavirus outbreaks are under control, say Spanish authorities
facebook twitter google+
The Week

Dear Varkeychan,

Among those caught out by the UK’s sudden “handbrake restriction” on arrivals from Spain was Transport Secretary Grant Shapps, who had just begun a holiday in the country at the weekend.  

Like everyone else, Shapps will now be required to self-isolate for 14 days on his return.

The cabinet minister may be feeling confident he will still have his job at the end of it. Others, with less flexible employers, have expressed fears that they may not be so lucky.

from Arion McNicoll,
Editor, TheWeek.co.uk
@TheWeekUK
	

from Arion McNicoll,
Editor, TheWeek.co.uk
@TheWeekUK
main headline

daily briefing
Ten things you need to know today
1. Spain insists it is safe after UK launches new quarantine
Spain says it is safe to visit despite outbreaks of new coronavirus cases. “Spain is safe for Spaniards and for tourists,” said the foreign minister after the UK abruptly ordered people coming from the country to quarantine. The UK’s move to require arrivals from Spain to self-isolate for 14 days came into effect on Sunday.

2. Over-40s may pay more tax to tackle social care crisis
People over 40 would start contributing towards the cost of care in later life under plans being considered by ministers to end the crisis in social care. Over-40s would have to pay more in tax or national insurance, or be compelled to insure themselves against “hefty bills” for care when they are older, says The Guardian. Last year, Boris Johnson vowed to “fix the crisis in social care once and for all”.

3. Speaker fears No. 10 briefings will sideline Commons
Parliament could be sidelined by plans for daily televised press briefings from Downing Street, the Commons Speaker has warned. Sir Lindsay Hoyle told the BBC he was worried the proposal was “not the way forward” and insisted that major announcements should always be made in Parliament first. No. 10 is planning to trial daily televised press briefings from October, modelled on briefings from the White House.

4. Anti-obesity drive to include ban on in-store promotions
Buy-one-get-one-free deals on unhealthy food will be banned as part of the government’s drive to tackle obesity. There will also be restrictions on where foods high in fat and sugar can be promoted in store and new guidelines for displaying calories on menus. Boris Johnson said the plans would help “reduce our health risks and protect ourselves against coronavirus”.

5. Portland demonstrators bring down courthouse fence
Protesters in Portland have brought down a steel fence around a courthouse after days of trying. Federal agents fired teargas and “non-lethal projectiles” to drive back thousands of demonstrators surrounding the courthouse to demand Donald Trump withdraw the paramilitaries. The Guardian says Portland is the focal point of nationwide protests sparked by the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis in May.

6. Regulator to get tough on airlines over holiday refunds
Regulators are poised to launch a crackdown on airlines that have failed to refund families for flights cancelled due to coronavirus. The Daily Telegraph says the Civil Aviation Authority is understood to have drawn up a list of the “worst culprits”, with millions of customers still owed billions of pounds after being told they could not fly. The body may threaten carriers with a ban from operating in the UK.

7. Republican senator says slavery was ‘necessary evil’
A Republican senator has called the enslavement of millions of African people “the necessary evil upon which the union was built”. Tom Cotton, who represents Arkansas, is introducing laws to prohibit use of federal funds to teach the 1619 Project, a project from the New York Times that reframes US history around August 1619 and the arrival of slave ships on American shores for the first time.

8. Health experts call for lift on magic mushroom ingredient
Restrictions on the active ingredient in magic mushrooms are blocking potential treatments for severe depression, addiction and other mental health disorders, scientists and politicians have said. According to clinical trials, psilocybin may be a safe and effective medicine for patients with certain psychiatric illnesses. Experts are urging ministers to order a review of psilocybin and remove the obstacles faced by researchers.

9. Star from Hollywood’s golden age dies at age of 104
Olivia de Havilland, one of the last remaining stars from Hollywood’s “golden age”, has died at the age of 104. During her career, which spanned more than 50 years and almost 50 feature films, she appeared in Gone with the Wind. She was a pivotal figure in getting actors better contracts. At the time of her death she was the oldest living performer to have won an Oscar.

10. Elon Musk challenges Johnny Depp to a cage fight

Covering the government’s anti-obesity drive, the Daily Telegraph tells readers to “Lose 5lbs and save the NHS £100m”. It features a photograph of Boris Johnson walking a dog.

Meanwhile, the Daily Mail says the “bombshell” book about Harry and Meghan is likely to “scupper any hopes of renegotiating their royal duties” in the future.

Good Morning Varkeychan,
‘Panta rhei’ said Heraclitus, a Greek philosopher circa 535-475 BCE.

It’s loosely translated into the oft-quoted “change is the only constant in life.”

True then. Even truer today.

Before I go any further, let me introduce myself. I’m Nithin, a fresh face at The Ken and its first dedicated writer for the daily newsletter, Beyond the First Order, shortened to BFO. We write about the changes we see in India – in tech, policy, healthcare, business, and money.

If you remember, my colleague Jum had introduced you to our newsletters a few days ago too.

Today, I’m going to talk about how India is changing, and what it means for all of us. In our lives. In our careers. It affects all of us. Some of us may be employed at a company. Some of us may have struck out on our own. Whether we like it, or not, change is happening, at a pace faster than ever.

Let me show you an example of this change. I’ll illustrate this using a sector I understand and follow quite closely — personal finance.

The graph below shows the average lifespan of companies in the US over the years.


It’s a similar story in India when seen through the lens of its stock market index, the NSE Nifty 50. The index saw 50% of its constituent companies churn over the past decade.

Things change.

And India’s sweeping reforms in 1991 accelerated a lot of these changes.

Suddenly, government run institutions took a back seat. In banking, private banks entered the fray. Today, the once mighty public sector banks are like dinosaurs on the brink of extinction, merging with each other in order to survive. This probably means more job losses, fewer promotions, and more competition for the staff who always felt secure in their jobs.

Shortly after private banks came the non-banking financial companies. They changed the way Indians spent their money. Credit was easy to come by and people’s aspirations grew. Traditional money lenders were hurt. Even private banks started losing out.

When discount brokerages started popping up in 2011, incumbents were quick to write them off, but today the traditional brokers are a dying breed. Soon, engineering teams which never found their place in a stock brokerage formed the backbone of its operations.

Over the years, distributors of mutual funds have seen their earnings dry up as a sea of regulations engulf them. In the 2000s, it was the abolition of entry charges for mutual fund investments and in the 2010s, it was the introduction of lower cost commission free plans along with a distinct regulation of fee-based investment advice. Fintech companies mushroomed to reach investors at scale. Entire lives and careers have been disrupted.

And mutual funds themselves are today at the risk of being disrupted by fintech companies that put the power of investing in the hands of investors. It is also enabling a host of financial experts to reach a greater audience by offering subscription-based investment portfolios.

Change is here. It’s faster than ever. It’s more pronounced than ever. And it’s more impactful than ever.

The only way out is to stay abreast of this change.

Luckily, that’s what we do on a full-time basis at The Ken.
Today’s premium story

Today’s story, which we’re unlocking for you, is about one such change but at a country-wide level.

India is hoping to ride on the $13 billion Adani Group, the world’s largest solar power developer, to take a big leap in solar module and cell production. But, this ambition still has to face China which holds the key to India’s clean energy future.

You see, China is home to 94% of the global production capacity for silicon wafers. A key component of solar production.

With border disputes on the rise and China losing its pole position slowly as the manufacturer for the world, India might have a foot in the door, but it’s an uphill climb and it still needs China.

Read this fascinating tale by Seetharaman.

The Chinese eclipse over India, Adani’s solar manufacturing dreams.

Nithin Sasikumar
Newsletter Writer

Good Morning Varkeychan,

It’s Day 25 of the challenge. Just 5 more days to go.

I’m Manan and I’m the Product Manager at The Ken.

Perhaps you’re wondering what a Product Manager does at a company like The Ken — a subscription media publication that has a journalism product. Well, I build products to drive growth and to give our subscribers a great experience. Often, this is neither easy nor straightforward. There are a lot of trade-offs involved. That’s what Product Managers do — they absorb these risks, make decisions and calibrate the results.

Allow me to show you this with an example.

Let’s say you are a media publication that publishes one story a day to your paid subscribers. You send an email to your subscribers every morning with a link to the story on your website. To read it, the subscriber clicks on the link, is taken to the website and can read the story after logging into their account.

What if I told you that this publication that publishes one story a day, which takes a subscriber an average of 10 minutes to read, decided to build a mobile app just six months after launch?

Why did we do this?

Well, initially, our thinking was that the mobile app was a way to replicate the reading experience of a subscriber from the web to an app.

But over time, quite recently, we found out that we were wrong. So three years later, in March 2020, we took an unusual call. We decided to dump our app and rebuild one from scratch.

Why did we do that? Because two things became really clear to us.

    For a subscription publication to succeed, an app isn’t just desirable. It is necessary
    All our earlier assumptions for why we needed to have an app were wrong


    For traditional news publications, the app drives user acquisition. That’s why they focus on app rankings, reviews and ratings.
    For traditional news publications, the app is an engagement channel, to send push notifications and to make users spend more time on it.
    Finally, for traditional news publications, the app is a monetisation channel to show ads.

For a subscription-based publication, the reasons are somewhat different.

In fact, subscription-based publications need an app because it solves problems that only subscription-based publications face.

Most apps where subscribers discover content—Twitter, Facebook, Gmail, WhatsApp, and others—have their own in-app browsers with their own individual session stores. Subscription publications limit the number of simultaneous sessions. Naturally, subscribers end up getting logged out, prompting them to log back in frequently.

Publications go to great lengths to solve this problem. We’ve our own approach, too.

There’s another reason.

At The Ken, longform articles—stories—are our core product. Since last year, when we introduced The Nutgraf, we now have three subscriber newsletters that have quickly become subscriber favourites. And we’re launching a podcast soon.

But for subscribers of The Ken, the app is where it all comes together. Subscribers find the day’s longform story and the day’s newsletters right at the top, seamlessly weaved into the home screen. No reason to go through various apps and websites.

And the way we built it was through feedback from our subscribers.

That’s more or less what Product Managers do. Not just at The Ken, but in most organisations.

They look closely at existing assumptions, and try to think of new ways to solve old problems.

And sometimes, we manage to put a smile on some faces.
Today’s premium story

The story that I’m unlocking today is one that’s close to my heart…and career.

From door-delivery to dog-walking, startups these days have turned everything into a ‘product’ that needs to be sold. But not everyone can sell these products. And not everyone can plan and execute them as well.

With the lines between product and services blurring, there is now a need for a new type of manager—the product manager (PM).

Sometimes they do everything. Sometimes, they don’t have to do anything. Their roles are fluid, changing according to requirements. Which is why you’d be hard-pressed to find a specific job description for these types of jobs.

Project Manager is dead. Long live the Product Manager

But the requirement for them is growing. On Naukri.com—India’s number one job search portal—listings for “product managers” jumped 14% between May 2018 and January 2020. Exactly double the growth of overall job listings on the website.

But even as PMs are being recruited in droves, the role of the project manager, the original PM is slowly growing obsolete. They are from a different era in IT and are not quite equipped to navigate the paradigm shift that products have caused. And now they’re rebranding themselves as PMs.

Today’s story explores this significant new trend in Indian tect and the conflict that this new role has brought on. Why does everyone want to be a PM? What is the future of this career path? What are its requirements?

Project Manager is dead. Long live the Product Manager.

Manan Bharara
Product Manager
